any reason?
because you can't go from 9.04 to 10,10
oh really?? so is it possible to upgrade from 9.04 to 10.04 ?
never mind, I've just googled it. Know the reason now, must go each-by-each distribution

i recommend you 1) back up your home folder. (and any other data). 2) do a clean install of 10,10 3) plan the partitions like so : 1-swap(no mountpoint) : 2g, 2-system (mount: / ) 20gb  3-home (mount: /home ) the rest of the drive space.
also, only do a dist-upgrade if you want to play with broken debris.

you might have no problems or you might end up with a totally broken system.... a clean install with that partition plan will help you do future clean installs far more easil and more reliably than any dist-upgrade will.

because I have a lot of settings (i.e. thunder bird email accounts, shortcuts to network drive, compiz, cairo, firefox addons etc.)... cannot install from scratch now... it may take a month to re-config these things
all those settings are in your home folder
you'll have to do them from scratch anyway if your upgrade fails ... a stitch in time saves nince
up to you really... im just sayin... since you want to end up at 10.10 you'll be enduring the gamble of two upgrades

the reasons I want to update is because 9.04 hang on shutdown (network drives not unmounted thing), even they are unmounted, system may hang sometimes.... also Wifi drops randomly if overloading ~30MB/s

they're good reasons... but i *highly* recommend that you put /home on a separate partition so that you simply skip all this upgrade nonsense and simply clean install (and tell the installer to use you old home partition as the new home)
have never tried before because I thought if I install thunderbird for an example, it may not realise the thing inside /home folder, and so other programs
well that's where it puts its settings in the first place.
ok let me try, thank you :D
its how i moved from 9.10 to 10,04 and after i installed 10,04 my desktop looked *exactly* like it did in 9.10... if you didnt sit through the install you;d think i didn't have a new version.

the difference between dist-upgrade and clean installs with separate partition is that you will *always* end up with a usable operating system... but if you rely on dist-upgrade... its a gamble
